title: Market overview: FTSE finishes in negative territory
text:
10.316 0.000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - 1630 (Close): The FTSE closed lower after an unexpected slowdown in UK construction activity growth and as concerns over Greece continued to weigh on sentiment. The Markit/CIPS PMI on UK construction eased to 57.1 in July from 58.1 a month earlier, missing forecasts for a reading of 58.5. The Athens stock market fell for a second day as worries about the country's finances dragged. Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) was leading the fallers as the Dublin-headquartered pharmaceuticals group made a hostile takeover approach for US immune deficiencies specialist Baxalta (Berlin: 9BX.BE - news ) at roughly $30.6bn, only a month after it was spun out by Baxter International (NYSE: BAX - news ) . 1600: US stocks are little changed amid a slate of earnings and a report that showed US factory orders rose in June. Office Depot (NasdaqGS: ODP - news ) is trading higher even though its second quarter sales missed expectations. Twitter (Xetra: A1W6XZ - news ) gained despite opening at an all-time low after the social media giant closed at a record low of $29.27 on Monday night. Toyota fell despite posting a record first quarter profit fuelled by a weak yen, although the group would have reported a decline in operating profit had it not been for the favourable currency impact. 
1500: US factory orders rose 1.8% in June, as expected, following a 1.1% drop a month earlier, the Commerce Department reveals. 
1445: The ISM's New York index rose to 63.1 in July from 63.1 in June, well above the 50 level that indicates expansion. The index measures the performance of the business sector among firms in the New York City. 
1107: Producer prices in the Eurozone fell 2.2% year-on-year in June compared with a 2% decline in May, in line with expectations, according to data released by Eurostat. Prices in the energy sector tumbled 7%, while non-durable consumer goods dropped 1.1% and intermediate goods fell 0.6%. Prices rose by 0.7% for capital goods and by 1% for durable consumer goods. 
1000: Greek stocks are suffering a second day of losses after tumbling as much as 23% on Monday. The overall Athens General Index .ATG was down around 4 % after opening higher as investors worried about a new bailout from the European Union and reacted to Greece's worsening economy. 
1225: Greek government spokeswoman Olga Gerovasili on Tuesday said the country expected to conclude a bailout deal with its international creditors by 18 August, with the drafting of the accord starting on Wednesday. "The first phase of negotiations ends today and the second phase starts, which really contains the details of drafting (the deal)," Gerovasili told Greece's Skai TV station. 
0930: UK construction sector activity growth slowed in July amid a weaker rise in housing activity. The Markit/CIPS purchasing managers' index fell to 57.1 in July from the previous month's 58.1, trailing estimates for a reading of 58.5. Nevertheless, a number above 50 signals expansion in the industry. "July's growth slowdown is the first for three months and perhaps a sign that the post-election impact on construction confidence has started to diminish," said Tim Moore, senior economist at Markit (NasdaqGS: MRKT - news ) . 
0900: London equities slumped, led by natural resource related stocks as commodity prices weakened. A measure of mining shares were in the red, including Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) , Anglo American (LSE: AAL.L - news ) and Fresnillo (Other OTC: FNLPF - news ) , as gold and silver prices declined on the Comex. The mining sector continued to reel on worse-than-expected Chinese manufacturing data on Monday, adding to concerns about the slowdown in the world's second largest economy.
